Looking ahead in this pandemic has been difficult. But it’s necessary.

And today the signals of what may come are there for us to observe.

We don’t get out of this if we don’t fight tomorrow’s battles. And so far we’re not. end/

Sadly for many parts of the world the tragedy is already unfolding.

Our relative feeling of safety here fuels the crises around the world and eventually back home. 24/

And at home Republicans in Congress have created a stalemate & uncertainty. Our ability to move fast, more essential than ever to keep up with the virus, is more important than ever.

We are hamstringing ourselves in a battle we already aren’t winning. 23/

Congress is rightly committing another $40 billion to fighting the war in Ukraine. Its what leaders do. 

But we’re now unwilling to spend a penny around the globe on vaccinations. We ignore this problem at significant peril. 22/

Critical to being able to keep up is full participation from Congress. To solve future problems we need to see around corners & make those investments.

Not just to develop new & better vaccines more rapidly. Not just to buy them here. But to increase vaccinations.21/

In the war of science be the virus, science scored major victories with vaccines which reduce death & therapeutics.

But the latest battles have all gone to the virus and we haven’t been able to keep up. 20/
And that doesn’t account for the unforeseen impact of what will brew in China & North Korea in the face of major outbreaks, prolonged illness & new variants. 19/

And BA.1 and future versions are A LOT different. So whatever the late in coming data tells us this summer might be irrelevant.

Even if we plan to update vaccines, once/year, we are barely at that pace. And with the virus changing 3-4 times/year, it’s just not enough. 18/

We began testing an omicron vaccine just after Thanksgiving with the goal of producing a new one in 100 days.

Nearly 200 days later nothing. Worse still, the BA.1 we began testing on is long gone.

By the time the Fall gets here it will be BA.5 (in SA today) that is ripping.17/

Item 3: Our scientific options.

Here goes. A rapidly evolving virus with massive new stores of infection will be harder to respond to scientifically.

We’ve been given reason to have faith in the “rapidly adaptable” mRNA platform. At best, it is not rapid enough. 16/

There have been fewer more disastrous lines of thinking than the “herd immunity/let her rip” crowd. Not only did it kill people then@& not provide herd immunity, but it didn’t do much to protect people who got it from continuing to. 15/

One expert told me this week that the virus, facing layers of immunity, is making rapid adjustments of its spike protein so it’s not just more contagious, but it penetrates previous protection more easily.

SA would seem to be evidence of this. 14/

Item 2: Our protection against new variant versions.

Being infected with older versions of Omicron don’t appear to protect us well against these newer versions or against older variants.

If this remains the case it portends a continuous reinfections potential. 13/

And South Africa, where newer & newer versions of Omicron are emerging, each iterating off the last raise some troubling issues.

Are we going to see a CONSTANTLY CIRCULATING virus every 4-6 months instead of a SEASONAL model? This year suggests an evolutionarily tough bug. 12/

A similar but perhaps more devastating crisis is also brewing today in North Korea. A closed country, unwilling to accept help in the form of vaccines or otherwise. Living conditions that are ripe for spread and a government that appears to be in denial. 11/

Will a massive outbreak in China rapidly spawn many new variants? Will there be spillover to animal reservoirs? Will the supply of life saving items we need worldwide manufactured in China become more scarce? How will this spark new shortages? 10/

Everyone is in a difficult position. But by all accounts I have received the needle on vaccinations hasn’t moved during this lock down.

If millions dying isn’t scary enough to contemplate, there will undoubtedly be spillover effects from a massive outbreak in China.9/

Millions of vulnerable, high risk people & a virus hard to contain as @KatherineJWu said on an upcoming @inthebubblepod that “the damn in China is about to break.”

The lockdown policies are becoming unsustainable but as soon as they end, we could see millions die. 8/

The second factor is the massively increased transmission of the virus from the 2020 version to Alpha to Delta to Omicron to B2 & beyond.

What may have been possible to contain by keeping the country closed no longer is. 7/

The first factor is that the country has not been successful in vaccinating high risk groups, in particular the elderly. And the vaccine available, Sinopharm, is not as effective as the mRNA vaccine.

The second factor is what makes the first factor so dangerous.6/

In China, the government was able to shut out earlier versions of COVID with strict policies.

Deaths, even if under-reported, have   been enviably low. But 2 things have happened which have caused things to become worrisome— one inside China, the other outside. 5/
Item 1: Today‘a happenings (tomorrow’s potential challenges) in China, North Korea, and South Africa are going to very likely create significant global fallout. 4/

But many of the trends we see, often around the world, that we pay less attention to become the seeds of later challenges.

-Outbreaks in new countries 
-Variant behavior
-Frequency of reinfections 
-Vaccinations 3/

Today’s events that we spend our time looking at— case rates, hospitalizations, reinfections— were  set in motion months ago. And while there are things we can do to keep ourselves & some others safe, it is too late to stop the wave that is here.  2/

COVID Update: The COVID we think we know one day has continued to evolve to something different every 4-6 months.

What’s happening now that’s painting the picture for COVID at the end of the year? 1/

When it comes to climate change, time really is running out. Earth Day is a reminder that if we pledge to do our part and then follow through on those commitments, we can help preserve and protect our planet for future generations.

It’s up to each of us to decide what we value, and to use the tools we’ve been given to advance those values. I believe we should use every tool at our disposal to secure our greatest gift – a government of, by, and for the people – for generations to come.
Solving the disinformation problem won’t cure all that ails our democracies or tears at the fabric of our world. But it can help rebuild the trust and solidarity needed to make democracy stronger.
Each of us has to pick a side. Do we allow our democracy to wither? Or do we choose to make it better? That’s the choice we face, and it is a choice worth embracing.

As part of this, tech platforms need to recognize that they play a unique role in how people consume information, and their decisions have an impact on every aspect of society.

Always great catching up with @POTUS. Thanks for all you’re doing to help even more Americans get access to quality, affordable health care. https://t.co/vDYBIxjIy9

It’s good to be back at the White House! Tune in as I join the @POTUS and @VP to celebrate the Affordable Care Act and talk about how they're taking action to make it better.

https://t.co/PlAKrFD6cN

Progress often feels slow, and victories are sometimes incomplete. But the ACA shows that if you believe that we can improve people’s lives, and if you’re willing to work through obstacles and continually improve, you can make America better.

But the ACA was never perfect, and we always knew we would have to make it better. That’s what @POTUS has done since taking office. Today, he’s going even further – lowering premiums for nearly 1 million people and helping 200,000 more uninsured Americans get access to coverage.

The ACA also lowered prescription drug costs for 12 million seniors, and allowed young people to stay on their parents’ plan. And it’s eliminated lifetime limits on benefits that often put people in a jam.

Because so many people made sacrifices and some members of Congress took courageous votes, we got the ACA across the finish line. Now, more than 30 million Americans have health coverage, and 135 million Americans with pre-existing conditions can’t be dropped or denied coverage.

Passing the ACA was incredibly difficult. People who had coverage were worried about losing it, the media was skeptical, misinformation was flying around, and Republicans showed no interest in working with us. But Joe, Harry Reid, Nancy Pelosi and I were determined.

The Affordable Care Act is an example of why you run for office – not just to occupy a seat, but to make a difference in people’s lives.

Today I’m joining @POTUS and @VP at the White House to celebrate everything the ACA has achieved, and help make it even better.

I mean that's kind of an overstatement, for most cities. We don't need anything that big! But big dense developments with lots of housing middle class people can afford and raise a family in, near outdoor greenspace and walkable commerce.
Very few people's idealized conception of What Cities Should be are big Mitchell-Lama towers, or Stuy Town, but actually that's what we need way way more of.

But that was a kind of accident, the culmination of a bunch forces - many pernicious! - that shouldn't be a model for the future. The future won't look like the past and it may even be aesthetically a bit cringe! But that's OK.

The key insight is that a lot of people want to "go back" in a way to a certain moment in urban development that, for a confluence of reasons created relatively affordable, vibrant, walkable, bohemian-friendly neighborhoods.

Despite George Floyd being killed with a cop's knee on his neck for 9 minutes 2 years ago, the killing of unarmed young Blacks & Latinos in particular continues. The US Senate failed to support police reform. We will continue to fight for justice & the elimination of racist cops.

When will this country come together to denounce and deter the killing of innocent children and adults by heavily armed killers in a society where guns are so easily accessible? Another recent mass killing of 14 children in Uvalde, Texas, by an 18-year-old! Gun Control now!

The Justice Department has a responsibility to identify and track down white supremacists and domestic terrorists who have taken certain identifiable criminal acts that define them. The FBI must make arrests and follow through with appropriate convictions.
When the justice system acts promptly to apprehend and convict white supremacists who prey upon Black, Asian and other minorities, perhaps this can be a deterrent to the killing of innocent people.

White supremacists are lurking in this country, and Black people, particularly those highly visible, are vulnerable. The right-wing haters must take responsibility for their rhetoric, actions, and hatred against black people.

For many of us, our lives are in danger every day. The attacks and threats we receive from white supremacists are real. This atrocity by a white supremacist in Buffalo is unforgivable and cannot be simply dismissed as insanity.

Happy birthday to my dear friend & genius Stevie Wonder. Thanks Stevie, for Radio Station KJLH. Thanks for the wonderful songs you have entertained us with! Thanks for initiating MLK's birthday celebration. Thanks for your support for freedom, justice, and peace for this country.

Happy Mother’s Day, mothers everywhere! Thank you to my children & all, who have wished me a Happy Mother’s Day. Let’s all remember our mothers do for us what they know how to do. Most of the time, what they do works well, sometimes not so well. However, love conquers everything!

Today the women of this country have gotten the first view of a leaked document from the SCOTUS that basically describes the destruction of Roe v.Wade. This decision will be devastating. Despite the pending decision, women must fight with every breath of life, to resist & resist!

I will continue in the struggle, for fairness and justice at every level of our society. Despite the threats, I have no fear, and I cannot be intimidated. My life has long been dedicated, to the struggle for equal justice, fairness, and respect.
We must all be committed to justice, fairness, equality, and a criminal justice system that respects us and protects us, rather than abuses us.
We need to get rid of recycled cops, that go from one jurisdiction to another despite having records of abuse and disregard for the very citizens they are supposed to protect and serve.
Everyone must play a role in changing the police establishment, that for too long has abused its power and taken advantage of having a gun and badge to use against innocent people.

We need to confront racism, police abuse, and elected officials who fear police organizations and refuse to confront them. We need real public relations programs put forward by police departments to interact with the community, for the community.

We need police reform in this country. We need diversity and inclusion in the Criminal Justice System in this country at every level. We need the United States Congress, to adopt the police reform legislation that has been passed in the House and has been stalled in the Senate.

The George Floyd killing in Minneapolis, the killings of Breonna Taylor, Philando Castile, Sandra Bland, Freddie Gray, Elijah McClain, all of them black, along with the killings of many more Blacks and Latinos, continue to create volatile tension.

The question is, has there been any progress since that time? We certainly have changed police chiefs, some better than others! But there is still a lack of trust in the police and situations can still end up with unrest.
I considered the confrontation on these issues to be a renewed resistance to police brutality, and a feeling of having been dropped off of America's agenda.

I took to the microphones, & I described my understanding of the anger, the distrust, and the feelings of being trapped with nowhere to go. No jobs, no careers, not enough food, and the constant shadow of hostile police, targeting unarmed young black men in particular, for abuse.

My description and discussion of the unrest that took place on April 29th, 1992, described the miserable conditions and police abuse that was so prevalent in Los Angeles and in communities of color in particular.

In the following days, while working on the street, responding to radio calls and telephone interviews, I defined the unrest differently from many outside observers, who claimed the unrest was just a bunch of criminals who wanted to steal and destroy.

I organized to get food, baby diapers, and medicine to the public housing units in South LA, starting with Nickerson Gardens, Jordan Downs, and Imperial Courts housing projects. I then began to work on getting the lights turned on that had been stopped as a result of the unrest.
The next day I made my way to the Public Housing developments in LA because I knew that the poor people there would be isolated and separated from grocery stores and other resources.

Upon arriving in LA on April 29th, the day the insurrection took place, I saw that the streetlights were out, and water was streaming through the streets. The police were everywhere. I got to my home and prepared to deal with the unrest unfolding in the streets.

I immediately reserved a seat on a plane to Los Angeles. During the plane ride, rumors were being spread, that the plane upon entering LA airspace, was going to be targeted with gunshots as a part of the insurrection that was taking place. The rumors did not prove to be true.

Today, I am remembering 30 years ago, I was in Washington D.C. when the news flashed, describing, "LA Riots” that I referred to as an insurrection, following the nonguilty verdict of the Los Angeles police officers who had viciously beaten Rodney King.

Happy Easter to all the children and their families. Thank you to the White House for opening up to our children, for the White House Easter Egg Roll. I am delighted that the families and children attending will be able to see their President at this special annual celebration!
